article_title: The Establishment of the Idrisid Dynasty

paragraphs.text: The Idrisid dynasty, considered the first Shia dynasty to reach power in the Islamic world , was founded in Morocco in 172 AH (788 AD) by Idris ibn Abdullah . Idris ibn Abdullah, a descendant of Imam Hassan , fled Medina after the Battle of Fakhkh in 169 AH . The Idrisids are believed by many researchers to have followed the Zaydi Shia branch . The dynasty exerted control over the West African region for three centuries .

sections.subtitle: The Role of Idris I and Rashid

paragraphs.text: Idris I arrived in Volubilis (Walili) in 778-779 after allying with the Berber Awraba tribe . Rashid led Idris I to Volubilis from Mecca, passing through Egypt . The Jewish tribes took on a political role in the subjugation of Morocco to Idriss I . After conquering Tangier and Volubilis, Idriss I sought to persuade the Jewish tribes to join his army . Idriss I attacked and plundered some Jewish cities like Temesna, Chellah, and Magada, prompting Jews of Tadla, Fazaz, and Shawiya to join his army under "general" Benjamin-monta Joshaphat-monto Abiezer . After some successes, the Jewish contingent withdrew from Idriss I's army due to their aversion to bloodshed amongst their 'brothers' . Idriss I retaliated against the Jewish community after their withdrawal . The Jewish communities ultimately made peace with Idriss I, agreeing to pay a yearly capitation tax .

While Idrīs I and Idrīs II are generally considered the founders of Muslim Morocco, Rāšid's role has been historically marginalized . Rāšid succeeded Idrīs I and ruled for approximately twelve years . Rāšid minted coins in his name in Volubilis and Tāhirt, the Rustamid capital . The oldest anonymous coins found in Fès were minted during Rāšid's reign, suggesting he may have founded the city . Some historians initially identified Rāšid b. Qādim as an Abbasid governor, but Moroccan archaeologists later suggested he was a local prince . It is now argued that Rāšid b. Qādim was the regent for Idrīs II during his minority . Fulūs of Rāšid b. Qādim found in Volubilis and Tahert are similar to those of Idrīs II (175/791-213/828) struck in Volubilis . The fulūs of Rāšid b. Qādim are also analogous to those of the Rustumid ʿAbd al-Wahhāb b. Rustum (r. 167/784-199/824) struck at Tahert and Tlemcen . The type of fulūs minted by the Idrisids and Rustumids is distinct from other coinage in the Maghreb at the time .

In less than a year, Idris's authority extended from Tlemcen to the Rif of Tamasna, and from Tangier to the Oum Er-Rbia River . The Abbasid Caliphate ceded authority over Morocco to the Idrisid dynasty in the 8th century . The Idrisids integrated with tribes in the Fès region to initiate widespread Islamization .

sections.subtitle: The Founding of Fez and the Shift in Capital

paragraphs.text: Establishing a state requires a strong capital city as a base . Initially, the Idrisids resided in the city of Walili (Volubilis) . Idris ibn Abdallah founded Fes in the middle of the years 192 to 193 AH (Islamic calendar) . Idris II chose Fes as the capital, shifting it from Walili . The construction of Fez started on Thursday, Rabi’ al-Awwal 192 AH / 4 January 808 AD . Idris II founded Fez and made it the capital of the Idrisid state . Idris bin Abdullah built a city on the right bank of the Fez River in 172 AH / 789 AD . The historical city of Fez was considered the capital of the Idrisid state from the middle of the third century AH / ninth century AD . Favorable geographical and strategic factors allowed the Idrisid rulers to govern effectively from Fes . Fes became a hub for scholars, traders, and a successful industrial zone under Idrisid rule . The founding of the Medina of the Idrisids (VIII-IX centuries) led to the silting up of the travertine system .

Idris II, after building his capital in Fez, launched a campaign in 197 AH/812 AD towards Nefis and the Masmuda tribes, successfully imposing control and incorporating Aghmat . Following the death of Idris II, his son Muhammad divided the state among his brothers. Abd Allah received Aghmat, the land of Nefis, the Masmuda, and the Souss .

The Idrisid State flourished due to attention given to women and their views being incorporated into governance . Women in the Idrisid State played a vital role in intellectual life across culture, economy, scientific advancement, architectural art, and power structures . Kenza, wife of Idris I, was a key figure who provided advice to rulers and held a prominent position among the Berbers . Kenza was instrumental in maintaining the Zaydi ideology after the death of Idris I . Kenza influenced Idris I's decisions and played a role in dividing the Idrisid territories among his sons and grandsons . Fatima al-Fihri (Umm al-Banin) founded the al-Qarawiyyin mosque in Fez in 245 AH, which became a major center of learning . The construction of al-Qarawiyyin was financed by Fatima al-Fihri and involved using materials from the land she purchased, reflecting her religious commitment . Al-Qarawiyyin is considered the oldest university in the world still in operation . Maryam al-Fihri, Fatima's sister, founded the al-Andalusiyyin mosque in Fez . Atika bint Ali ibn Omar al-Idrisi played a key role in her father assuming power during a period of unrest .

Ibrahim bin al-Aghlab founded the Aghlabid dynasty in Tunis in 184 A.H./800 A.D. . Ibrahim bin al-Aghlab defeated insurgencies from the Idrisids and Kharijites in Ifriqiyyah . The Idrisids "never established very firm or wide-ranging political or Shia religious authority, but it did bring Islam to the ‘Far West’ of the Muslim world" . The Idrisid Dynasty (788-974) was seen as the hope for Shi‘ites fleeing Abbasids’ persecution . In the 10th century (IVeH.), the Rif mountains provided a refuge for Idrisid princes who were under threat from the Fatimids of Tunis and the Umayyads of Cordoba . The Zanata replaced the defeated Idrissids with the Kutama being defeated .

The Idrisid dynasty existed from 788 to 921 . The Idrisids were partially integrated into the Fatimid camp, while other branches resisted . Musa b. Abi l-'Afiya, a Fatimid agent known for his hostility towards the Idrissids, later joined the Umayyads . The rise of the Fatimids resulted in the disappearance of several political entities including the Idrissids . No remains exist of the Idrisid Palace built in Agadir . The destruction of the Idrisid palace is seen as evidence of the diminution of sovereignty and the demise of their power and legitimacy .
